titleStmt.title: Notes on Administrative Matters, Edward Waters College, 1924-1925
titleStmt.author: Unknown

publicationStmt.p: This document was produced as part of the project "Northeast Florida Editing Workshop" at the University of North Florida.

msIdentifier.repository: University of North Florida, Thomas G. Carpenter Library Special Collections and Archives

msContents.summary: Handwritten notes pertaining to the curriculum, enrollment, income, and expenses of Edward Waters College in Jacksonville, Florida for the school year 1924-1925.

objectDesc.p: The note consists of two handwritten pages and is in generally good condition, with some darkening, stains, and creases.

editorialDecl.p: This file was transcribed and encoded according to the editorial criteria of the project "Northeast Florida Editing Workshop" (nfew.org) at the University of North Florida. Using the various options encoded within <choice> elements, this file enables the viewing of a diplomatic transcription and a regularized reading text.

body.p:
Supported wholly by contributions from
the negro people of the state of
Florida, through the A.M.E.African Methodist Episcopal
Church, 11theleventh Episcopal District.
The African Methodist Episcopal Church grew out of the Free African Society and was dedicated in 1794, under Pastor Richard Allen. The church congregation became an independent institution in the early 1800's, after Pastor Richard Allen successfully sued the courts of Pennsylvania for this right.
Dickerson, Dennis C. "Our History." The Official Website of the African Methodist Episcopal Church. https://www.ame-church.com/our-church/our-history/ Accessed August 29, 2020.
Governed by a Board of Trustees
elected by the people throughout
the state. The presiding Bishop
is the chancellor of the insti-
tution. It is co-educational
and does not limit its stu-
dents to any particular
faith. The enrollment for
1924-25 is approximately
550. The Collegecollege conducts
classes beginning with the
6thsixth Gradegrade and continuing through
four years of college work
and, in addition, maintains
body.note: The top of the note is marked with a printed logo, which is crossed through with pencil. The printed logo portrays two crossed American flags positioned above the words "U.S.A. Camp Johnston Jacksonville, Fla."
body.p:
a theological seminary
Possible reference to Lee Theological Seminary for the
proper training of ministers.
It also has business, printing,
tailoring, domestic science, and
domestic art departments.

The amount of money
raised each year for the
operating expenses of the
school, including board
and tuition paid by students,
totals very nearly $100,000.00.

The needs now are the estab-
lishment of a sufficiently large
endowment fund so that the
school might be able to take care
of its needs and obligations with
some degree of assurance and not
depend wholly on the free will offering of the people.
